It is well known that every group action of a fixed group G on sets can be encoded as a functor {G} → Set, where {G} is the one-object-category version of G.

I am trying to work this out in the setting of continuous group actions. Now, I know this wont' work in Top since you require that the category be Cartesian closed, so let's use instead the category Conv of convergence spaces, which is Cartesian closed.

Also, it seems we need to work in an enriched setting: If G is a convergence group, then the one-object category {G} needs to be Conv-enriched. I don't think I need to enrich Conv though.

Is there anything else I need to do here? Also, any reference to this construction in the continuous setting would be greatly appreciated.

Because the functorial definition defines actions as morphisms of type G → (X → X) and you need uncurrying to turn this into G × X → X.

That makes these two things equivalent in a ccc, but you can still always use the latter if you merely have products (and this is what I normally consider the definition of a group action).
Ah I see you were already discussing something very similar here.

So I would consider @Kevin Arlin 's description of the Lawvere theory for monoid actions if you want a functorial representation. You can extract the category of actions of a specific monoid as a subcategory of that to avoid the problem you were encountering with the fixed monoid Lawvere theory where the monoid elements are discrete morphisms in the theory.
Yes, I could start using Lawvere theory, but I am still curious if the functorial representation {G} → Conv would work.
You can express it as an internal functor category, but cashing that out turns everything into products anyhow.
Do you happen to know of any paper or book that works through it?

To make the Lawvere theory idea explicit, let CM\mathcal{C}_{M}CM​ be the Lawvere theory of monoids, CM,X\mathcal{C}_{M,X}CM,X​ the Lawvere theory of a generic monoid action. There is a functor Z:CM→CM,XZ: \mathcal{C}_{M} \to \mathcal{C}_{M,X}Z:CM​→CM,X​ picking out the monoid part (it's actually a full subcategory if I'm not mistaken), which induces a functor Z∗:[CM,X,D]→[CM,D]Z^*: [\mathcal{C}_{M,X}, \mathcal{D}] \to [\mathcal{C}_{M}, \mathcal{D}]Z∗:[CM,X​,D]→[CM​,D] from a given action to its underlying monoid.
For a given monoid MMM in D\mathcal{D}D there is a functor ⌜M⌝:1→[CM,D]\ulcorner M \urcorner: 1 \to [\mathcal{C}_{M}, \mathcal{D}]┌M┐:1→[CM​,D] identifying it, and actions of that monoid are the pullback of Z∗Z^*Z∗ along ⌜M⌝\ulcorner M \urcorner┌M┐.

Here's an approach that seems closer to what you want (though it's possible you can get this from Morgan's comments, I haven't checked).

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a cartesian closed category (as you were expecting) and GGG a group object in C\mathcal{C}C. Then there's an associated one-object C\mathcal{C}C-enriched category BG\mathrm{B}GBG, where we take a single object ⋆\star⋆ and define Hom(⋆,⋆)=G\text{Hom}(\star,\star) = GHom(⋆,⋆)=G.

Now we have two ways of defining an action of GGG on an object X∈CX \in \mathcal{C}X∈C.

  1. We could look at an arrow α:G×X→X\alpha : G \times X \to Xα:G×X→X in C\mathcal{C}C satisfying the usual axioms
  2. We could look at a C\mathcal{C}C-enriched functor F:BG→CF : \mathsf{B}G \to \mathcal{C}F:BG→C sending ⋆↦X\star \mapsto X⋆↦X.

In definition (2), we're crucially using the cartesian closed-ness in order to view C\mathcal{C}C as being enriched over itself.

The key way of translating back and forth between these two perspectives is to remember what a "C\mathcal{C}C-enriched functor" is. It has to send objects to objects (for us we send ⋆↦X\star \mapsto X⋆↦X) and hom-objects to hom-objects. That is, there had better be a C\mathcal{C}C-arrow Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(F⋆,F⋆)\text{Hom}(\star, \star) \to \text{Hom}(F\star, F\star)Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(F⋆,F⋆).

But Hom(X,X)=Hom(F⋆,F⋆)\text{Hom}(X,X) = \text{Hom}(F\star, F\star)Hom(X,X)=Hom(F⋆,F⋆) is the C\mathcal{C}C-object given by the internal hom [X,X][X,X][X,X]. So taken together a C\mathcal{C}C-enriched functor BG→C\mathsf{B}G \to \mathcal{C}BG→C is given by the data of an object X∈CX \in \mathcal{C}X∈C and a C\mathcal{C}C-arrow G→[X,X]G \to [X,X]G→[X,X].

As you intuited, this is exactly the same story as the Set\mathsf{Set}Set-enriched case, since the data of such an enriched functor uncurries to exactly the data of an internal group action G×X→XG \times X \to XG×X→X by CCC-ness of C\mathcal{C}C.

Now you can work in your favorite convenient category of topological spaces in order to play this game with continuous group actions. ^_^
